facts.text: Appellant was a resident of Ratangarh in the Princely State of Bikaner outside British India.
On November 6, 1945, appellant started a business in Calcutta; relevant accounting year from November 6, 1945, to April 9, 1946.
Appellant assessed to income-tax for 1946-47 as a non-resident British subject.

On January 19, 1946, appellant came to Calcutta with 11 ten thousand rupees notes and 158 one thousand rupees notes, total value Rs. 2,68,000, encashed through Punjab National Bank under High Denomination Notes Order.
Appellant credited Rs. 2,68,000 in books of Calcutta business as capital received from him.
Appellant explained notes came from his father who died in 1942.
Income-tax Officer held explanation not supported by books/documents, treated Rs. 2,68,000 as income from undisclosed business activities, taxable.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed appeal, held books/documents showed notes part of assets devolving from father, deleted Rs. 2,68,000 from assessment.
Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Appellate Tribunal.
Tribunal dated August 7, 1953, allowed appeal in part: Rs. 1,28,000 as concealed profits liable to tax, Rs. 1,40,000 as capital.

Appellant Mohanlal's adoptive father was partner in Manekchand Tarachand in Calcutta till 1906, left with large sum, started own business Kaluram Mohanlal till 1925-26, then retired to Ratangarh, died April 22, 1942.
Appellant succeeded to father's estate including the notes.
Appellant relied on father's books at Ratangarh continued by him, containing entries of numbers of ten thousand notes and existence of one thousand notes.
Tribunal found father wealthy, retired 1906 with Rs. 6-7 lakhs, started own business Calcutta, had substantial moneys in Bikaner State Savings Bank 1926-1942.

Tribunal rejected Ratangarh books as genuine: no Calcutta business books produced; no entries of receipt from closed Calcutta business; books only record bank transactions and accommodation loans; numbers appear in loan entries; incomplete record 1926-1942.
Tribunal: from 1926-1945, only source of income interest on bank deposits; appellant had Rs. 8-10 lakhs in bank ~1945; impossible to have another 7 lakhs in notes.
Appeal to Supreme Court under Article 136.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Denomination Notes of Rs. 2,68,000 encashed by appellant represented assets from his father's estate or undisclosed income.
Whether Tribunal's finding that Ratangarh books not genuine and Rs. 1,28,000 as income was based on no evidence or unreasonable view.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal's finding that notes not proved from father unreasonable, no evidence or view no judicially instructed person would take.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mehta Parikh & Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal's estimation of uninvested cash and sources speculative.
Even if income, no finding it accrued in British India; assessed as non-resident.

respondent_arguments.text: Notes represented undisclosed income; Ratangarh books not genuine.

court_reasoning.text: Supreme Court does not reassess evidence or come to own conclusion on facts; intervenes only if fact-finding authority acted without evidence or unreasonable view.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal's reasons for rejecting books reasonable and supported by evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal's view on books possible; cannot appraise evidence afresh.
Tribunal's further observation on income sources and estimation a concession to appellant, not affecting main finding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Criticism of speculation does not assist appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Territorial nexus point not raised earlier, cannot be allowed now.

holdings.text: Tribunal's finding that appellant failed to prove notes from father's estate reasonable and supported; Rs. 1,28,000 taxable as undisclosed income.
Supreme Court will not interfere with Tribunal's factual findings unless perverse.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mehta Parikh & Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for Supreme Court intervention in factual findings of Tribunal.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave to appeal from Tribunal judgment.

statutes_cited.name: High Denomination Notes Order
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions under which notes were encashed.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Tribunal's order upheld, including Rs. 1,28,000 as undisclosed income taxable; no interference with factual findings.

key_quotes.text: The Court would be entitled to intervene if it appears that the fact finding authority has acted without any evidence or upon a view of the facts, which could not reasonably be entertained...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for interference with Tribunal's factual findings from Mehta Parikh.

key_quotes.text: It is not the practice of this Court to do so [reassess evidence].
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits Supreme Court's role in factual matters.

key_quotes.text: We are unable to say that the reasons given by the Tribunal... are unfounded or that there was no evidence to support the view that the Tribunal took.
key_quotes.speaker: court
